nodes.text: Reporting both the ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth rate and the time-average (DDP per capita) growth rate, plus their difference (ergodicity gap), provides a better-informed and less misleading picture of national economic performance than reporting GDP per capita alone
Ergodicity economics asks whether stochastic processes used in economic models are ergodic; if not, ensemble averages and time averages can differ

Model income dynamics as random multiplicative growth (Gibrat-type) and apply the ergodicity transformation ln(x) so that changes in ln(x) are stationary and ergodic; derive growth rates from changes in ln(x)
The ensemble-average growth rate (growth of the arithmetic mean of income) corresponds to GDP per capita and is approximately an income-weighted (plutocratic) average of individual growth rates

The time-average growth rate is the long-time growth experienced by an individual, equals the average of individual log-growth rates, corresponds to DDP per capita (geometric mean income), and is a democratic 'one person, one vote' measure
Under multiplicative stochastic growth, the ensemble-average growth rate exceeds or equals the time-average growth rate (Jensen's inequality), producing a non-negative difference

For multiplicative growth with stationary independent shocks, the rate of change of ln(x) is ergodic and its ensemble and time averages coincide as mathematical expectations, while the growth rates of the arithmetic mean and the typical trajectory differ

Analytic GBM example: for geometric Brownian motion dx = x(mu dt + sigma dW), ensemble-average growth g_ensemble = mu, time-average growth g_time = mu - sigma^2/2, so ergodicity gap grows at rate sigma^2/2 and increases without bound in the model

The time-average growth rate and the ergodicity gap (mean logarithmic deviation, MLD) depend only on the initial and terminal income distributions and are independent of rank mobility, allowing estimation from cross-sectional (quantile) data

Empirical evidence from World Inequality Database: between 1966 and 2014 the United States shows divergence where GDP per capita outpaced DDP per capita (g_ensemble > g_time) since ~1980, while France shows much closer ensemble and time-average growth rates

Estimate time-average growth and DDP per capita from quantile (percentile) average data by computing changes in the mean of ln(x) across quantiles; apply truncation of very low incomes to reduce sensitivity

Relying only on ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth can mislead policymakers because it measures growth of total/average income (plutocratic) while the typical individual's long-run experience can be worse when g_ensemble > g_time, creating political disconnect

Model and data limitations: geometric/divergent GBM is a null model with no interactions or redistribution, DDP (geometric mean) is sensitive to small/zero incomes so truncation is used, and real economies may contain reallocation or correlation effects not captured here

Conclusion and recommendation: statistical authorities should compile and report ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth, time-average (DDP per capita) growth, and the ergodicity gap (MLD) because together they distinguish aggregate productive-capacity growth from typical individual experience and reveal inequality dynamics
